citations.desc: Information as to business; furnishing of same by dealers, exhibitors, operators of auction sales, intermediate handlers, and carriers.
citations.narrative:
The facility did not respond to request for information regarding the disposition/acquisition of the following animals: One
goat, one llama, one alpaca, one wallaby, one duck, and one emu that were present on the October 31, 2024 inspection
and were not counted at this inspection. There was one more domestic cow counted at this inspection compared to the
October 31, 2024 inspection. A follow up email was sent to the facility on December 13th, 2024 which was not answered
at the time of delivery of this report. No representative was available at the facility from 10:30am to 11:05 am on
December, 17th 2024 to answer questions and complete an exit interview and no phone calls or texts were returned.
Failure to furnish information requested by inspectors during an inspection inhibits the ability of inspectors to conduct a
thorough inspection of all aspects of the facility and determine compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. In addition, failure
to answer questions regarding serious animal welfare issues, such as possible animal deaths, prevents APHIS from
ensuring potentially severe non-compliances are properly addressed.
The facility shall furnish to any APHIS official any information concerning the business of the dealer, exhibitor, operator of
an auction sale, intermediate handler or carrier which the APHIS official may request in connection with the enforcement
of the provisions of the Act, the regulations and the standards in this subchapter.
Correct by December 20, 2024

There was an extension cord for the water pump in the group avian enclosure that ran on the ground through the
enclosure of two capybara and two black swans.
Extension cords that the animals can access may cause injury or death if bitten or if the animal becomes entangled.
The housing for the capybara must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury
and contain the animals.

There was a large accumulation of fecal material and contaminated hay surrounding the hay feeder in the enclosure
housing, one sheep, five domestic cattle and 12 goats.
Lack of cleaning of primary enclosures can lead to parasite infestation and other diseases.
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.

The primary enclosure housing the two black swans and two capybara and the primary enclosure housing two African
Crested porcupine have rodent holes in numerous areas.
Lack of a pest control program to eliminate rodents can lead to contamination of food, water, and the animal environment
and may cause disease in the captive animals.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be
established and maintained.

There is an electric extension cord in the primary enclosures for two black swans, two Egyptian Geese, one Mandarin
duck, sixteen peafowl, and seven pigeons that the birds have access to.
Extension cords that the birds can access may cause injury or death if bitten or if the bird becomes entangled.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
To be corrected by December 13th, 2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
- There are rodent holes entering/exiting the enclosure of the two sacred ibis on all four side of the outdoor and indoor
portion of their enclosure.
-There are numerous rodent holes around the black swan and capybara enclosure. The primary enclosure for the two
Egyptian Geese, one Mandarin duck, sixteen peafowl, and seven pigeons has numerous rodent holes around and under
the enclosure.
Lack of a pest control program to eliminate rats and mice can lead to contamination of food, water, and the animal
environment and may cause disease in the captive birds.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the birds.
This inspection was conducted with a facility representative.
No facility representative was available to conduct an exit interview either via phone or in person on November 17th,
2024.
Additional Inspectors:
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
